Review will continue to be updated as I play through the game

Crashlands
Crashlands is a humorous and well-done large world RPG set on an alien landscape. Combing elements of survival, story, and humor to create an amazing title. I will add a TL;DR at the end.

Gameplay
You are Flux and you are handling a urgent delivery with your robotic companion Juicebox. Your ship is destroyed by quite the purple head thingy... yeah.  You are now stranded on an alien planet and have to try and establish communication again and survive on the planet with its hostile environment.

The controls within this game are fairly simple using the mouse to either click and you will move there or hold it and you character will move where your mouse is. Crashlands also utilizes the A S D F and C V buttons as quick buttons, the A S D F buttons can be changed to quickly use your items while the C and V buttons are for your wonderfully murderous pet. The game mechanic is done well and I can see how easily it is converted to its mobile counterpart. Crashlands has a large amount of customizable floors and walls with useless furniture to behold. The game does a nice job of guiding you through everything and learning the game with rather comedic moments with Flux and Juicebox whether it be between themselves or the non-hostile inhabitants of the planet. The combat mechanic in the game is very fun as it requires you to be intelligent about you approach with every creature you see, which wants to kill you.... which is almost the entire planet. This game also removes the hassle of having to manage you inventory because apparently you have black hole pockets, just don't question it and be happy. Other than the expected do quest, get gear, and farm stuff mechanics you would expect of an RPG you can also rip the eggs from the creatures you kill and then raise their baby to murder their past brethren, overall very nice as long as you don't think too much on how STWOMPY (My personal Wombit) killed over 100 of his own kind already along with other creatures (so proud). The only problem is having to go back to old areas to remove bits of black so I can see the whole map, as it's quite the long process.

Graphics/Sounds
The graphics are cartoonish and more innocent than anything else. They are polished and very smooth and the evolution screen while you evolve your pet is quite majestic to watch. The music is alright and the sounds match the creature well.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Great survival element
+ Good amount of customization
+ Large game allowing you to play for hours on end
+ Cross-platform saves

Cons

- Annoying to have to go back to previous areas of the map to fill it out without black areas
- Moments where a crafting recipe I was tracking is replaced by a quest item track when I talk for the quest (slightly annoying, perhaps an option to not automatically change the tracked recipe?)
- Grinding is existent and prevalent within the game

Suggestions
These are my personal suggestions that I feel would improve the game.

- With the editor major update (when it is released) there should be an option to create custom player models and creature models to help create a true sense of freedom through customization in the update.
- If the created creature is hostile the ability to select its attack patten would be amazing
- Workshop for maps and mods with the large scale update
- Ability to have Vanity items" meaning that you could be waring one item for stats
date: but you can use another item that you prefer visually to be seen on you\n- Ability to see pet stats. To be able to see stats such as growth (Ex 26/100 and when it is evolved #/300)

and unique attack chance.
- Future Co-op feature

Final thoughts
I played Don't Starve and it was nice

reviewText:
I wasn't sure what to expect from this game.
Whatever it was I was expecting, this game FAR EXCEEDED my expectations.
This game is fun. It oozes a special something, and it just makes me happy.

You can tell this game was made by people who love games.
It respects your time. There's no level grinding. There are generous teleport pads across the open world, and you can teleport to any of them at any time (once you've discovered each one).
You have infinite inventory, so you never have to worry about managing what to collect or not-collect. You want to just collect everything.

The game lets you play however you want, at your own pace.
There's no penalty for dying. You WILL die. You will drop some of your items when you die.
Simply go back to where you died, and you instantly pick them all up again. You move on.

This game is about enjoying the world that has been created by the team at Butterscotch Shenanigans.
The story seems really large, with many side-quests. It's all open world, so you can complete anything at any pace you want, and any order.

The game just feels good.
I also recommend picking up the mobile version of the game. Your save will automatically sync between both versions of the game, so you can always play wherever you go. That's another sign of a game developer who truly cares and respects the player!

If you're looking for a game to get lost in, this is the game to be playing.

reviewText:
This game was reviewed with a key from the developer

Summary:
Crashlands starts out of the gate with a good sense of humor, and takes you on an adventure that I enjoyed despite some of my problems with it. The game is very basic in the action RPG genre, and it shows some of its mobile elements (as the game is also available on mobile devices) with some of the control elements and mouse drive controls. With that said, the combat can give a challenge with its sorta give and take gameplay, and it's complemented by a crafting system that has some depth to it. It's a game that took elements that I normally don't enjoy, like “home building” systems, and made them enjoyable for me. It's got a good sense of humor with its small jabs and wit here and there, and the game comes together well as an overall package to deliver a fun experience. I've got 10+ hours in it, but I've seemingly only scratched the surface, as while the game can get repetitive, it definitely delivers on the content in terms of items to collect and craft. Whether it be on Steam or on the mobile platform (if you have something like a Galaxy Tablet, it definitely works well there) (and there's cross platform play), Crashlands is a fun time all around, and is best suited for the kind of adventuring player that wants to take in the sights, and enjoy the trek along the way.

Video Review: https://youtu.be/VfIkIobolnA

Lists:
+:
The game is a sum of it's parts. Every element of the game, even the elements that I find to be negatives, work well together to make the game a sum of its parts. Picture a set of gears working together to power something. That's this game.
Building system is very easy to use and easy to rearrange things with. Very straight to the point, and gets the job done without over complication.
Like the crafting system, especially with the weapons element. Multiple attempts makes sense for weapons and armors due to rewards of higher calibur weapons. Gives reasons to recraft and recraft.
Boss encounter and high amounts of enemies in one area definitely bring a strong impact. Surprisingly difficult at times, even at the normal difficulty.
Pets actually make a reasonable difference in battle, especially the bigger ones. They aren't just there for show.
There's a lot to do. You can spend a lot of time just exploring to get more items to craft with, and finding new schematics and what not. Those wanting to just get lost in minecraft like elements will enjoy themselves here.
Game's combat does have a sorta fencing like style to it, and can be challenging in some aspects. Simple, and straight forward, but it works despite its flaws.
Like the fact that there's cloud saves that works cross platform. Those wanting to do both will enjoy the fact that this seems pretty straight forward.
Sense of humor that knows the power of subtle touch, and not banging you over the head with the joke. It's obvious the developers had fun creating this game from the ground up, and it shows with the execution. Little things like the big baddie showing up out of nowhere to zap the tree I was about to chop down made things a bit more interesting.
Great aesthetic. Enemy designs are nice and actually feel a little fresh compared to other games in the genre, and yet still have some familiar aspects to them. Good color choices as well.
Like the items that were designed to collect items via bombs. Smart.
Performance is there. Never dropped under 60 FPS under normal conditions, and even when my machine was doing other significant tasks, it held on to it then too. The machine is up there in terms of specs, but still was surprised.
-:
Game suffers in control areas, most likely due to its mobile counterpart. It will take some adjusting, especially in tight gameplay areas where its easy to click on something in the middle of battle.
Would want to see some better menus and quest tracking. Having some information on the main screen about your next objective would have been appreciated. Some hints on where to get certain materials will go over some players heads.
Wanted more hotkeys honestly. Understand the simplicity and the mobile portion, but 4 hotkeys made switching things in and out for easy a little bit more trouble some that it was worth. Especially with the fact that you can't switch items in battle.
Game will get repetitive for some, as while there are things to change it up, combat will be against a lot of the same enemies early, and there's fetch quests. Some map legend elements would have helped this.
The map implementation can be very annoying, as your natural reaction is to click to drag the map, only to have you teleport to the nearest teleporter.
Those looking to have their hand held in terms of what to do with quests and items to find will not enjoy elements of this game. Reading quests information and looking at items to determine what you need to is required.
Would have liked to see the options menu be available from the pause menu, as opposed to only via the title screen.
On a side note, it reminds me how badly I am at interior design.

There's crafting, survival, cooking, fishing, building, questing, and plenty else to do in this game. Crashlands is REALLY good, and each of its mechanics is so well done, you'll wonder why other developers hadn't thought to do it this way.

Storyline and Gameplay

For starters, this game is pretty funny. It doesn't take itself seriously, and has jokes and humour littered througout. The thing is, it's all quite well done, and creates an enjoyable world to explore and discover. The characters you'll meet are often silly and entertaining, but not in any way that breaks immersion. Overall, it's very well done, and by doing the storyline quests and side quests, you unlock more recipes and ingredients to use to make your character even stronger.

Crafting

reviewText:
Gad damn where do I begin??
At the beginning I suppose...
It all started back when a buddy of mine [Mr. Food] invited me to the St. Louis IGDA (International Game Developers Association) which is basically an awesome group of like-minded people that get together once a week and talk about games and more specifically game development (tips, tricks and tools). It's really awesome, check out: www.igda.org to see if there is a chapter in your city (If there isn’t one, you can start your own!) The very first time there- two cool dudes took the stage, Sam and Seth Coster…
and they proceeded to describe an amazing game that they were working on and I remember thinking to myself holy ♥♥♥♥ that would be incredible!

Well guess what???
THIS IS THAT ♥♥♥♥ING GAME!!
And it truly is everything the Super Coster Bros described that fateful day.

From a story aspect:
Right off the bat, the dialogue will make you laugh out loud (LOL) and the humor never fails to deliver throughout the game! It’s much more story driven than the majority of crafting style games out there. It is filled with cute (and sometimes dangerous) little creatures and the NPCs you meet along the way really breathe character (pun intended) into the game (love that Juicebox). It really sucks you into the world. Also, the title is a great little pun (that you Crash-land, but you probably already noticed that).

From a gameplay aspect:
I’ve never played a crafting game with such smooth functionality, everything is so polished and the controls feel so… natural! I didn’t know if I would like that almost everything is mouse controlled (except for some quick select buttons) but they’ve integrated the majority mouse control style so well that I don’t miss the keyboard! (It appears to be very touch-screen ready, which will be fun to see if Crashlands makes it onto iOS and Android, and to have a ‘Deepworlds’ kind of situation where you can switch from playing on your computer to on your smartphone seamlessly). The combat is some of the best I’ve ever seen in mouse-only control scheme (really, the mouse movement does not hinder you at all), the enemies will show their red [damage] ring and you can dodge out of the way quite nicely, however it’s not that easy, every enemy has their own attack personality and you will find yourself getting to know each enemy on a personal level! The build mode is also really well designed, you can lay down floors, walls, etc with serious ease! Heck, just listening to the build mode music is worth it! I LOVE that you can “recycle” tools, weapons, buildings basically everything, and it will give you the resources back! Another great thing is finding schematics, you never know where or what you’re gonna find; all I can tell you is you will get super excited every time you see a crate! It gives you just enough to make the crafting aspect fair and actually enjoyable (it doesn’t feel so much like a chore, but more that you want to cut down ♥♥♥♥!) but it doesn’t spoon feed ya either!

From a aesthetic aspect:
(I’m not sure if I’m using that word correctly, what I mean to say is graphics/sfx/music all that audio/visual stuff) From the start you notice that Crashlands has a graphical style all its own and it is truly the trademark Butterscotch Shenanigans style that is unlike any other. (In fact, Sam did a presentation on how he uses Inkscape to make his awesome little creations) I find it refreshing to see these kind of unique graphic styles (don’t get me wrong, I love pixel art but it’s nice to see something new once in a while) there is a sort of ‘brutal cuteness’ to Crashlands and it fits the game’s personality like a [Wompi]glove! The music is excellent, composed by FatBard (another cool guy who did a presentation on game music at IDGA St. Louis) from the upbeat daytime music, to the soothing nighttime track and even the awesome build mode elevator muzak; it compliments the graphic style so perfectly! In fact, I feel as though the music is audible version of BScotch’s graphics (if that makes any sense at all). Everything down to the adorable little beeps and boops that characters make when you talk to them, to the epic “TOOL INTEGRATED” splashscreen, to just the quirky flavor-text of the items and tools (Baconweed™ is good for me!) everything ties together so magically delicious(ly).

All-in-all:
Even though I might seem biased because I’ve met the Coster brothers (and they are REALLY AWESOME guys, super nice and funny, as you can imagine!) Crashlands really is an incredible little game (actually it’s not little, in fact the world is quite huge!) At first glance, it may seem like it shares many similarities with Don’t Starve, but the second you start playing you will find that Crashlands is such a unique and fun experience all its own. It is a testament to the true indie game; handcrafted by real-life brothers, who poured their hearts into this sweet little baby… And it shows!
Best of luck BScotch Shenanigans, and CONGRATULATIONS on an awesome game!

reviewText:
They have Baconweed

THEY HAVE FREAKING BACONWEED

It's like a weed... but it's made of bacon

Ok, I appreciate that did very little in selling the game to you. But what it does tell you is how seriously Butterscotch Shenanigans takes their game...

Answer: Not very

What we have here is the aim to take out everthing tedious from world-sprawling RPG's... and just make them all about fun. So the guys blasphemously ripped out many of staples we're sick of... Letting us focus on the important things: Beating up the local wildlife and collecting stuff to make bigger stuff to beat up bigger local wildlife. So we no longer have to manage an unweildy inventory and angrily raid about 50 chests for that 1 item we know we picked up somewhere, but likely left in an outpost in God-knows-where (yay). The map is littered with teleporters that let us hop around the place on a whim (yay). And if you die, you can just go back, pick up your stuff and carry on (yay)

On the surface, this might seem worrying. By removing all this, does it leave a rather shallow game? Not really. What it ultimately does is make it exceptionally approachable and give you the freedom to muck about and just... enjoy it. Seriously, I could just mill about the Savannah for ages - it was just so relaxing. That's not to say it's easy (you will die... a lot), but it's laid back and easy to dip into.

The only real weak point is the armour crafting. Basically, your kit will randomly have special effects when you craft them (poisoning, going berserk, resisting damage...) - but it cannot be carried over when you upgrade. This sucks big time, as you'll repeatedly end up with Excellent Level kit... then have to forge like 30 items of the next level in the hope that one of them will actually have bonuses worth upgrading to. And you're forced to upgrade A LOT (the enemies scale quite dramatically). It ironically adds a lot of tedium to a game hell-bent on removing it. It's frustrating and can detract from the enjoyment - but there is at least enough enjoyment to be had to mitigate it to a degree.

Other than that though, it's great fun! The combat is reminiscent of the old Mega Drive platformers: Studying the attack patterns and finding the sequences to best get a hit in. The pets are an inspired (and fun) addition and the writing is utterly wonderful. It's cheeky, playful and there are tons of laugh-out-loud moments to be had. The characters are brilliant and the item descriptions equally funny. The end is charmingly sweet and rounds it off perfectly.

All I can echo is the same thing I said to my partner smack-bang during my first boss fight: Holy crap this game is so cool!" - (then buying her a copy immediately after)

Little tip... pay attention to the names (especially the Polari) - They snuck in a lot more jokes than meets the eye..."

Look...if you love Don't Starve, Terraria, Minecraft, and/or Starbound, or maybe even Bastion, Diablo, Torchlight, etc., you will probably like this a whole bunch.  It has that resource gathering, crafting, upgrading loop thing going on quite well.

I can't recommend this game enough, I wish I could give it 2 thumbs up...like Siskell and Ebert, only with less snobbery.

reviewText:
Crashlands gives you a massive, hilarious, and, omg, narratively compelling, lore-rich open world to run around in, digging stuff up and chopping stuff down; bashing enemies over the head, setting them on fire, freezing them, poisoning them, or, my favorite, electrocuting them en masse; stuffing the corpses of your enemies and displaying them for all to see; taming your enemies' babies, bonding with them to get Fancy Battle Powers, and making them slaughter their own kind on your command; and helping a mess of cool NPCs sort out their troubles.  It is awesome.

I'm a story person, so that's what most impresses me about Crashlands.  Each of the game's biomes has a dominant culture, with its own stories, history and, no lie, values.  You get a few glimpses into the ancient history of civilizations that came before the ones you're helping now, too.  Lest this make you squint with the sudden suspicion that the game is anything less than a total blast, let me return to hilarious.  Crashlands' content is by turns aww-cute funny, terrible-pun funny, creepy funny, what-the-heck-surreal funny, and heaps of regular HA! funny.  You can do as many of the side quests as you want, or ignore all the NPCs' pleas and stay focused only on your main quest; I recomend doing every single side quest.  The whole experience is delightful.

Visuals are wonderful -- nighttime lighting effects are particularly beautiful, and creature design is distinctive, expressive, and again, hilarious.  I want a stuffed slurb, for example, so badly it's probably illegal in most US states.  Slurbs are just the best.  They're bouncy little razor-snails with pointy spikes on their shells and three blinky eyes.  And slurb on slurb carnage -- I can watch my pet slurb bounce the tar out of another one. . . basically forever.  I will never get tired of that.

More great things:
There is a cat boss, and the cat boss has a really cool story that comes out during the boss battle
Poison bombs, blood bombs, bombs made out of friggin seeds, bombs made out of bird fat, bombs made out of other bombs
A creature that vomits its own explosive larvae at you
Terrifying bug-things that split themselves into pieces, teleport the pieces, electrocute you with them, and reassemble themselves like that's a thing just anyone does on a Tuesday
Laser deer (trust me)
A sidequest series that seems like it's one of those little things that teach you how to play the game, basically, but then it sneaks up on you and becomes extremely emotional
Creeping sentient fungus landscape
A stat for your biceps
Did I mention the cat boss?  The cat boss is awesome
Get this game! It's not like you have important things you need to do in the next 3 or 4 weeks, anyway.

I could go on and on about the story, the characters, the studio, the mechanics, etc. but you've probably already read about all that.  If the waterfall of those positive reviews hasn't sold you yet, though, this probably will:

Check out the hours of record for the reviewers.  (At the time of this review, I've put in 46 hours: 15 on laptop, 41 on mobile.)  And I'm one of the light-weights.

The fact is that this game has crazy playability, which is rare for an indie title.  Most indie games that get noticed, much like independent films, tend to have tons of artistic merit and critical acclaim but nevertheless lack the plain fun and replayability of big studio productions.  CRASHLANDS IS DIFFERENT.

Part of what makes the game hard to put down is its balance.  Good games strike a magic balance between challenge and reward, giving us that wonderful sense of satisfaction and accomplishment.  For me, at least, Crashlands hits a sweet spot.  Whether I was Level 1 or 31, I always had a good mix of easy, challening, and just-out-of-reach objectives.

Another thing making the game hard to put down, is, well, how easy it is to put down.  With the crossplatforminess" between my laptop of phone
date: I've played Crashlands in 2 minute spurts and evening-sucking marathons.  Although the game has dozens of hours of content

reviewText:
I really wanted this game to be good, but sadly, it is quite primitive and lacking for its price.

You can clearly tell the game was designed to be played on a phone. The menus, combat, crafting, and gameplay are overly simple and leave a lot to be desired.

- With no skills and just basic items, the combat gets old within an hour or two.
- No way to change what craftables are being tracked without going back to crafting table
- No hover-over info in the UI, something ARPGs have had for over 20 years. You have to click an item to view its properties or what it is (You also can't hover over items in your tracked craftables, there also is no hotkey to move back in a menu, you have to press back). You also have to be at a crafting station to see what materials you have to craft with.
- Quest log is primitive and often not always clear what you're supposed to do.
- Crafting is on a time-based system. Appropriate for a phone maybe, but a waste of time and design on the computer.
- Combat is so basic that it becomes easy to master within minutes and never die.

Overall this game is probably fun if you spent $2 on it and played on your phone, but as a full-fledged steam release I expected more and feel underwhelmed and accepting of my loss of money.

I found this game through Youtube after seeing numerous Let's Players play and enjoy it.

I would first like to start out by saying that Butterscotch Shenanigans has quickly become one of my favorite video game producers to date. It is made up of three brothers that have shared their life story of their interest in video game design in their brief documentary called Dev Diary, which I highly recommend.

This is a group that knows how to make games, simply put. The combination of strong story-telling, logical game structure, and just the right amount of humor and wit makes any game they create a masterpiece in my eyes.

Now to Crashlands:

Crashlands is a Survival Action RPG with elements of Terraria's complexity, Don't Starve's play style, and the kind of awesome creativity that only Indie game producers have.

You play as Flux Dabes, an intergallactic shipment shipper who, after having her ship destroyed by a megolomaniacal alien by the name of Hewgodooko, finds herself stranded, along with her trusty robot sidekick, JuiceBox, on a planet called Woanope. Here, she must use here intuition and stick-to-it-iveness to fight, craft, and build her way back to the Bureau of Shipping to get her packages delivered!

One of my favorite parts of Crashlands is the combined elements of both RPG and Survival. As you traverse the alien planet, you will find numerous quest givers that are in dire need of your help, in return for a small reward, of course. Completing different quests allows you to craft new and more powerful items. This allows you to explore new areas, defeat new creatues, and climb up the seemingly never-ending tech tree towards victory.

TL;DR

If you like good games, good art style, good story, a good challenge, or even just good-old-fashioned fun, buy Crashlands. It is completely worth it.

- gets grindy and tedious

although I didn't finish the game and got bored of it, i still recommend it for people who are into these types of games.  i never played Don't Starve, but people are saying they are similar; so if you like Don't Starve, there is a good chance you'll like this game too.

reviewText:
What to say about Crashlands? Well i must say that it has consumed a lot of my free time for the past week. The game has a complulsive quality to it. Just five more minutes I tell myself only to quit two hours later. It pulls in ideas from Minecraft, Diablo and World of Warcraft. Yes, its derivitive, but what game isnt these days? It bucks the recent trend for rock hard perma-death games which I find really refreshing. I have always loved rogue type games but of late they have gotten too hard. I like to commit my free time but not to something that wipes out all my hard work when i make mistakes. Starting again from scratch I find far too frustating and I lose the will to play again. I guess the closest resemblance to recent games is Don't Starve, which I found a brilliant idea but ultimately i found it depressing. Quite apart from my character going mad every time it was far too hard and no fun after a while.

Crashland takes all these ideas and re-jigs them and the guys from the briliiantly named Butterscotch Shenanigans have produced a masterpiece (in my humble opinion). They then go one further and pull out yet another brilliant coup - they release it on multiple systems. This means that nerds like me can play the same game, nay the same game save on different systems!! Crashlands is on IOS, Android, Mac and PC. So i can start on my ipad, move to my Macbook Air when I fancy a change, then I can take the same game out on the road on my phone!! Wow!

What else? How long have you got? The game has an unlimited inventory. Collect everything to your hearts content. Want 500 blocks of wood, then go for it. The game also puts the right tool into your hand depending on what you are doing. For example, strike a tree and an axe comes to your hand, strike a rock and you automatically produce a pickaxe, hit a critter and your weapon miraculously comes to hand!

You also dont have to juggle stuff you own. The components you collect from scavanging and killing critters are listed briefly in a text panel over on the left of the screen then that is the last you see of them. You work with recipes instead, 500 of them in all, that are accessed by the numerous workstations that you also make. A recipe might need, ten sawgrass, three waterballoons and some glue. If you have all the components you can make it, as many as you have bits for. If not then the game tells you that you have x of whatever missing. So you go out and find it.

You also find eggs while out hunting. Find a recipe for an incubator and you can make it, then use it to hatch the egg. If you hatch a wompit you can create a nest and put it on it and then milk it! Yes milk it, Eugh! - you milk a one legged dog thing! Why? Because later in the game that milk is a vital ingredient in yet another recipe. The recipes themselves come from randoms drops mostly from kills while hunting. You also get the more important ones from completing quests. These are the workstations, the armour and the weapons and the major tools.

You will note I have said nothing about the plot or the setting. I wont either, suffice to says its ingenius and what starts out simple spins out into some grander. just do yourself a favour and buy it. Now!

To date I have clocked up 15 hours. So that leaves me 45 hours of playtime left according to the developers. I am still in the first map/biome. In one of the dev diaries which you can readily find on the net it takes eight, yes eight hours in realtime to walk from one side of one map to the other side! Thats mind bogglingly big. There are three maps!

I have played, in my considerable number of years of gaming life, very very few games for multiple hours, WOW, Wild Arms, FInal Fantasy games (all 14 of them) and Xenoblade Chronicles but never, apart from Alto, any game for so long on an ipad. Even on Alto i have only clocked up five or so hours. Crashlands has stolen the crown. It really is the bees knees and deserves to be played by everyone.

Are there any negatives? Well its a grind at times, but then I settle into the groove as i inch my way towards 140 blocks of stone and that blasted Wompit essence that was such a trial to get because the goal is so tantilising - a Wompit Garter which turns litle Chomp into a killing machine. So even the negatives turns into a plus.

I could go on, and on but I am feeling the itch to play. I want that level 7 helm but one component, a tiny blue flower bud, is so rare that I am having to trawl the entire map. When I do find it where it grows I will be sure to mark the map so after i harvest it I know where to go when it grows back. And that says it all, the total attention to detail the BS guys have poured into this game across the three years of its development.  Read their story too. Its quite moving.

The game is a wonder - go play.

reviewText:
Edited 3/29/2016: Do not mistake the fact that I haven't logged in in a while as a negative sign. I feel like there's at least 10+ more hours to be had from it. I only stopped because the third biome became quite difficult in contrast to the previous two for me personally. This game is terrific and worthy of your hard earned money (and then some - I could easily see it doubling in price and still being worth it).

PROS:

+ Keybinds (they're a godsend and quality of life upgrade)
+ Ability to take in the rich graphical beauty in full view.
+ Infinite inventory
+ Instant teleportation across the map to allocated teleport pads you discover as you explore.
+ Humor (this can be a con or pro depending on the person)
+ An in-depth crafting system with plenty to collect for hoarders and plenty of options for all types of players.
+ Cloud sync so you can load your save file on any device if you have it on each and continue where you left off.

CONS:

- Can get tedious and repetitive if you're trying to min max your stats by rerolling gear repeatedly.
- Movement speed feels slow sometimes and finding that attribute on gear that is also good gear is going to be pretty tough.
- Not very forgiving for mistakes in dodging enemy attacks (however, you can absolutely play on a lesser difficulty setting when you create the game)
- Cannot change difficulty of your game on the fly.

Counting the hours I've spent playing on IOS, I'm probably close to 10+ hours in and I've barely scratched the surface of the game, it feels like. I was a little unsure about whether or not I'd like the PC version, but now I can honestly say it is, without a doubt, the BEST version of the game. Moreover, the price justification needed to be there, and it is.

One of the only flaws I found with the game was on mobile platforms - tapping to move kept my finger in the way of what's going on, making avoiding attacks from enemy creatures more of a pain than it needed to be. At least for me. But that completely goes away here.

The graphics are wonderful and the way this game has improved upon the concept of Don't Starve is incredible. Absolutely everything was done right. Infinite inventory, the crafting system, pets that you can evolve (with a clever little homage screen to pokemon for their evolution), exploration, teleportation, the list goes on and on. Gone are the days of hiking back to your base by foot, or worrying whether or not you have enough inventory space left or whether you should pick up X item. Gone are the days of hunger and medical stats dragging you down (at least so far in my excursions).

The price tag is a lot more than on mobile platforms, but the game is absolutely 100% the same. So if you're strapped for cash and okay living without keybinds to open your inventory/quest log/build menu/etc, it's worthy of your time on any platform. But for those just interested in the PC version, who may be on the fence, do yourself a favor and buy it. If you liked Don't Starve, you'll LOVE this just as much, if not more, depending on the person. I myself can easily see many many more hours of this one in my future. You get your money's worth, that's for sure.

reviewText:
Had this game for the last week or so, have dumped 14+ hours into it so far, which means it's time for me to stop being lazy and write a well-deserved review.

BRIEF DESCRIPTION:

This game plays similarly to the Don't Starve franchise, if you've ever played that or watched someone play it, but is vitally different in a lot of aspects.  You play as Flux, a purple suit of armor with no thumbs and an infinite inventory that manages itself.  Along with your trusty robot companion, you are plopped onto a foreign world via spaceship crash, and it's your job to survive, re-ascertain contact with the company you work for, and eventually get home (I think, if you have one).  The game is sort of a 2D sidescrollerish game, but the world is completely open, filled with lots of little things for you to loot, kill, and ultimately upgrade your housing, weapons, gear, and crafting stations.  There are literally HUNDREDS of items to harvest and collect and craft.  Combat takes some accurate timing and getting used to, but it's loads of fun.


PROS:

-Nice graphics, very nice art style
-Fun combat
-TONS of things to collect and craft
-Infinite, self-managing inventory
-Tools that equip themselves only when you need them, and disappear when you dont so they're not in the way
-Lots of content
-Building stuff, in addition to the aforementioned crafting
-Lots of different enemmies with varying attacks and variations of the species
-Pets made from killed enemies that help you in combat with active attacks and passive buffs
-Great music
-Addicting
-Cross platform saving with mobile
-No permadeath, if you die you can just walk to your gravemarker and pick up the stuff you lost
-Teleports all over the map for fast travel

CONS:

-I wish it wasn't such a pain to navigate between sections of the world like the Savanna and Bawg and then get back to your original house without making another one.
-I'm honestly trying so hard to find flaws - but godamn I love this game.


TL;DR:

This game only costs $15, and if I had known how much I would enjoy it, I would have paid $40.  It's amazingly fun, with humorous dialogues, fun gameplay, and very intuitive crafting and item collection/use.  I would HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone, even if you're new to games of this type.  I wasn't a huge fan of Don't Starve, but I love this game.  I wish I could high-five the devs and buy them beer.


Easily 9/10.
